"Description": "Argo Bookshop is the oldest English-language independent bookstore in Montreal, located in the Shaughnessy Village since 1966. We're proud to offer a well-curated selection of fiction and non-fiction, including literature, poetry, science fiction and fantasy, science, philosophy, history, and biography. We also have sizable sections of young adult fiction and kids' books. We specialize in books on linguistics and Japan, as well as books on marginalized groups and by marginalized authors, including books on race, gender, and queer issues.",

Dates.notes: This event took place on FRIDAY, OCTOBER 30, 2020 AT 12:30 AM EDT

Content.contents:
84 people responded
Event by Ottawa International Writers Festival, VERSe Ottawa and Ottawa Public Library / Bibliothèque publique d'Ottawa
Online: writersfestival.org
Public  · Anyone on or off Facebook
Tun into this episode of our Writers Radio podcast as poet Nina Jane Drystek hosts conversations with Sachiko Murakami and Jillian Christmas, two incredible poets published by Vancouver’s Arsenal Pulp Press.
RSVP to get the link in your inbox or tune in when the episode is up: https://writersfestival.org/.../spotlight-on-arsenal-pulp...
Render is Sachiko Murakami's intimate and unflinching poetic memoir. In it, she travels the non-linear path of addiction to recovery, how it shifts over time, and what happens when it is translated through poetry. Looking beyond the straightforward, happily-ever-after narrative, Murakami wades through the aftermath of her addiction and questions what happens to trauma when it is put down on the page - and all the ways in which it can be rendered.
In The Gospel of Breaking, Jillian Christmas extracts from family history, queer lineage, and the political landscape of a racialized life to create a rich, softly defiant collection of poems.
Christmas draws a circle around the things she calls "holy": the family line that cannot find its root but survived to fill the skies with radiant flesh; the body, broken and unbroken and broken and new again; the lover lost, the friend lost, and the loss itself; and the hands that hold them all with brilliant, tender care.
ABOUT THE POETS
Jillian Christmas is the former Artistic Director of Vancouver's Verses Festival of Words. An educator, organizer, and advocate in the arts community, utilizing an anti-oppressive lens, Jillian has performed and facilitated workshops across North America. She lives in Vancouver.
Sachiko Murakami is the author of three previous poetry collections, including The Invisibility Exhibit (shortlisted for the Governor General's Literary Award). As a literary worker, she has edited poetry, worked for trade organizations, hosted reading series, organized conferences, sat on juries, and judged prizes.

Creators.name: Drystek, Nina Jane
Creators.notes: Event host

Creators.name: Murakami, Sachiko
Creators.notes: Bio taken from Facebook Post: Sachiko Murakami is the author of three previous poetry collections, including The Invisibility Exhibit (shortlisted for the Governor General's Literary Award). As a literary worker, she has edited poetry, worked for trade organizations, hosted reading series, organized conferences, sat on juries, and judged prizes.

An educator, organizer, and advocate in the arts community, utilizing an anti-oppressive lens, Jillian has performed and facilitated workshops across North America. She lives in Vancouver.

Content.notes: This content description taken from Facebook post for the event.
Content.contents:
201 people responded
Event by Tree Reading Series
Online Event
Price: Free
Public  · Anyone on or off Facebook

On Tuesday, October 27th, Tree Reading returns for another energizing, insightful and communal online poetry event, including a workshop by Stephen Brockwell (7-8pm EST) an open mic and featured readings by nationally acclaimed poets Lauren Turner (Montreal) and Jillian Christmas (Vancouver).
Every aspect of the event is totally free of charge and will take place online, via Zoom. In order to sign up for the workshop, the open mic, and experience the featured readings, we will ask you to fill out a Google Form and then e-mail you a Zoom link a few hours before the event begins.
The event will be hosted by poet and spoken word artist Brandon Wint.
Please be advised that all times listed are Eastern time. We welcome readers, open mic performers and featured readers from all over Canada and the world. Please note the time difference that coincides with your region/location.
https://t.co/SW6rb5BRAW?amp=1

FEATURED READERS---
Lauren Turner is a disabled poet and author of the full-length collection, The Only Card in a Deck of Knives (Wolsak & Wynn, 2020) and the chapbook, We’re Not Going to Do Better Next Time (knife | fork | book, 2018). Her work has appeared in Grain, Arc Magazine, PRISM, Poetry is Dead, Cosmonauts Avenue, The Puritan, canthius and elsewhere. She won the 2018 Short Grain Contest and was a finalist for the 2017 3Macs carte blanche Prize. She lives in Tiohtiá:ke/Montréal on unceded Kanien’kehá:ka land.

Jillian Christmas is a queer, black writer living on the unceded territories of the Squamish, Tsleil-Waututh and Musqueam people. An enthusiastic organizer and advocate in the Canadian arts community, her focus has been to increase anti-oppression initiatives in spoken word. She has executed programs in partnership with Toronto Poetry Project, The Chan Centre, Vancouver Opera, and more. Jillian has performed and facilitated spoken word workshops for youth and adults across the country and beyond. She is the author of The Gospel of Breaking (2020 with Arsenal Pulp Press).

Creators.name: Turner, Lauren
Creators.notes: Bio from Facebook post:auren Turner is a disabled poet and author of the full-length collection, The Only Card in a Deck of Knives (Wolsak & Wynn, 2020) and the chapbook, We’re Not Going to Do Better Next Time (knife | fork | book, 2018). Her work has appeared in Grain, Arc Magazine, PRISM, Poetry is Dead, Cosmonauts Avenue, The Puritan, canthius and elsewhere. She won the 2018 Short Grain Contest and was a finalist for the 2017 3Macs carte blanche Prize. She lives in Tiohtiá:ke/Montréal on unceded Kanien’kehá:ka land.

2 hr
25 people responded
Event by Caitlin Press and Planet Earth Poetry
Online Event
Price: Free
Public  · Anyone on or off Facebook
The first of our Tuesday night anthology readings will be the online Victoria launch of Sweet Water: Poems for the Watersheds, edited by Yvonne Blomer.
Bookseller for this event: Munro’s Books (250-382-2464 munrobooks.com)
Sweet Water: Poems for the Watersheds gathers the voices of poets from across Canada, the US and the UK who write of water. Bottled, clouded, held in rain, in river, estuary and lake, sweet water is the planet’s life force and the poets here examine it from every angle—the pitcher plant, the beaver and the American Bull Frog, rain, clouds, smog, the many ducks and the salmon and the last lake sturgeon. Poets take us to the rivers they live along—and grieve daily—the Peace River Canyon, Chilcotin, Taylor River, the Humber River, Millstone River, the Fraser River, and more.
READERS include: Alisa Gordaneer, Richard Harrison, Jeremy Pataky, Marion Quednau, Rhonda Ganz, Susan Stenson, Bruce Hunter, Zach Wells, Ulrike Narwani, Harold Rhenisch, Tom Nesbitt, Anita Lahey, Kirsten Pendreigh, Barbara Black, Maureen Hynes, John Barton, Terry Ann Carter, Marlene Grand Maitre
Zoom link: 
https://us02web.zoom.us/j/89835161487...
Meeting ID: 898 3516 1487
Passcode: 726758
Remember, you can also use the meeting ID and password to listen in on a landline or mobile phone! Find your local number:
https://us02web.zoom.us/u/kdgAWL2C1w

Content.notes:
107 people responded
Event by Bookhug and National Arts Centre / Centre national des Arts
Live on Instagram
Duration: 1 hr
Public  · Anyone on or off Facebook
Thanks to the National Arts Centre / Centre national des Arts, celebrated author Shani Mootoo will be doing a livestream reading from her the comfort of her home on Thursday, April 23, at 3pm EST on Instagram Live. Shani will read from her new novel, Polar Vortex.
Join Shani on Instagram at @shani_mootoo
The #CanadaPerforms series is co-sponsored by the National Arts Centre / Centre national des Arts, Facebook Canada, SiriusXM Canada, Slaight Music, and the RBC Foundation.
__________
“Polar Vortex is an unsettling novel about how secrets always come back to get us – especially the secrets we’ve managed to keep from ourselves.” —The Globe and Mail
"Apowerfully unsettling work from a brilliant artist.” —Madeleine Thien
"Polar Vortex is an honest, but also moving, exploration of true intimacy.” —Amitava Kumar
"A gorgeous and thrilling novel. Beautifully crafted, with perfect form and icy-clear tone—Shani Mootoo held me under her spell until the shock and release of the last page!” —Sarah Selecky
__________
About Shani Mootoo:
Shani Mootoo was born in Ireland, grew up in Trinidad, and lives in Canada. She holds an MA in English from the University of Guelph, writes fiction and poetry, and is a visual artist whose work has been exhibited locally and internationally. Mootoo’s critically acclaimed novels include Moving Forward Sideways Like a Crab, Valmiki’s Daughter, He Drown She in the Sea, and Cereus Blooms at Night. She is a recipient of the K.M. Hunter Artist Award, a Chalmers Arts Fellowship, and the James Duggins Mid-Career Novelist Award from the Lambda Literary Awards. Her work has been long- and shortlisted for the Scotiabank Giller Prize, the International DUBLIN Literary Award, and the Booker Prize. She lives in Prince Edward County, Ontario.

Creators.name: Mootoo, Shani
Creators.notes: Bio from Facebook post: Shani Mootoo was born in Ireland, grew up in Trinidad, and lives in Canada. She holds an MA in English from the University of Guelph, writes fiction and poetry, and is a visual artist whose work has been exhibited locally and internationally. Mootoo’s critically acclaimed novels include Moving Forward Sideways Like a Crab, Valmiki’s Daughter, He Drown She in the Sea, and Cereus Blooms at Night. She is a recipient of the K.M. Hunter Artist Award, a Chalmers Arts Fellowship, and the James Duggins Mid-Career Novelist Award from the Lambda Literary Awards. Her work has been long- and shortlisted for the Scotiabank Giller Prize, the International DUBLIN Literary Award, and the Booker Prize. She lives in Prince Edward County, Ontario.

Location.address: 401 Richmond Street West, Suite 350 Toronto, ON, Canada M5V 3A8

Item_Description.title: Canada Performs Livestream Reading with Shani Mootoo

Event by Les libraires, Librairie Drawn & Quarterly and 2 others
Online: quebecbd.com
Price: Free
Public  · Anyone on or off Facebook
Tout au long du 34e Festival Québec BD, nous collaborons avec le réseau Les libraires pour vous offrir des occasions de rencontrer des auteur.e.s de bandes dessinées québécoises.
Avec les dédicaces virtuelles, l’idée est de créer un groupe composé d’un maximum de 10 lectrices et lecteurs prêt.e.s à échanger et vivre une séance de dédicaces en vidéoconférence.
- DÉDICACE EN COURS -
AUTEUR : Pascal Girard
ALBUM EN DÉDICACE : Rebecca et Lucie mènent l'enquête (Éditions de La Pastèque)
LIBRAIRIE ASSOCIÉE : Librairie Drawn & Quarterly
DATE : Dimanche 23 mai 2021 à 14 h
***????????? : ?????? ?? ????? ?? ???? ??? ???????????? ??-??????? ?????????? ??? ????? ?? ?????? ??? ??????????? ??? ?? ???? ????????????.?? ???? ?? ????? ????????.
RÉSERVER MA COPIE : https://drawnandquarterly.leslibraires.ca/.../rebecca-et...
DATE LIMITE DE RÉSERVATION : 22 MAI À MIDI (heure du Québec)
????????????
Pour participer à une séance de dédicace virtuelle, vous devrez réserver une des dix copies de l’album associé à une librairie précise. Seules les commandes en ligne via la librairie associée seront acceptées.
Au moment de compléter votre achat en ligne, vous devrez inscrire « ???? ???????? » dans la section « ???? ??? ?? ???????? ».
Si vous souhaitez participer à plus d’une séance de dédicace virtuelle, assurez-vous que les deux albums sont associés à la même librairie. Si ce n'est pas le cas, vous devrez passez une commande par librairie différente.
Notez que vous êtes responsable de commander votre copie chez la bonne librairie.
Un courriel de confirmation incluant les détails concernant la séance de dédicace sera envoyé par un membre de notre équipe. Notez qu’il y aura un délai entre l’achat et ce courriel.
Nous inscrirons COMPLET dans la description de l’événement facebook et sur notre site web une fois les dix copies réservées.
Si vous ne pouvez pas être présent.e lors de la rencontre, votre copie sera quand même dédicacée par l’auteur.e si vous faites partie des 10 premières réservations.
Suite à la rencontre, votre album dédicacé vous sera acheminé selon la méthode sélectionnée lors de l’achat (par la poste ou chez la librairie associée). Pour tout achat de 39$ et plus chez le libraire partenaire, vous pourrez bénéficier d'une livraison gratuite.
Notez que les séances de dédicaces virtuelles vous sont offertes sans frais supplémentaires.
Pour toutes questions ou commentaires, contactez Maxime par courriel à maxime@quebecbd.com. See Less

Related_Works.citation: Pascal Girard, Rebecca et Lucie mènent l'enquête, La Pastèque, Montreal, 2021

Item_Description.title: Dédicace virtuelle - Pascal Girard - Rebecca et Lucie mènent l'enquête

Online Event

Argo Zoom Reading Series: Verse, Prose & Song
Thursday February 4, 2021 7 to 9 PM
Argo Bookshop 1915 Ste. Catherine St. West
https://www.argobookshop.ca/
Hosted by Adele-Elise Prevost & Moti Lieberman 514.931.3442
Curator Ilona Martonfi ilona.martonfi@sympatico.ca
Please email events@argobookshop.ca for the Zoom link
Louise Dupré published 20 books, including The Haunted Hand (La main hantée), translated by Donald Winkler, published by Guernica Editions 2020.
Ilona Martonfi is an editor, poet, curator & activist, her most recent poetry book is Salt Bride (Inanna, 2019). Forthcoming, The Tempest (Inanna, 2022).
Blossom Thom’s poems document Black experiences while playing with form. Her poetry has appeared in Montréal Serai, Kola, and elsewhere.
Kelly Norah Drukker is the author of the award-winning poetry collection Small Fires. She is currently at work on new poetry and nonfiction.
Brian Campbell, poet/singer- songwriter/editor/translator, latest collections, Shimmer Report & Passenger Flight. briancampbell.ca
Ann Lambert has been a playwright and teacher for over 35 years, and has just published her second novel.
Cora Siré is a poet, novelist and author of three books, including Behold Things Beautiful (Signature Editions, 2016).
Emily Tristan Jones, she’s been in The Puritan, Harvard Review, Vallum, and elsewhere. She facilitates for QWF and is editor of Columba.

Content.contents:
Details
3 hr
Event by Metatron Press
Online: eventbrite.ca
Price: Free
Public  · Anyone on or off Facebook
Join Metatron Press and a flurry of guest readers as we embark on a digital marathon reading of Diane Di Prima's Revolutionary Letters.

???????? ????
https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/127226256157/
Maximum 150 Guests
Fifty years ago, in 1968, Diane Di Prima began writing her "revolutionary letters," a series of poems composed of a potent blend of utopian anarchism and ecological awareness, projected through a Zen-tinged feminist lens. In 1971, Lawrence Ferlinghetti published them in the first edition of Revolutionary Letters as Number 27 in the City Lights Pocket Poets Series. By turns a handbook of countercultural activity and a broadside against the repressive state apparatus, Revolutionary Letters remains one of the vital classics of American poetry.
In gathering writers from all over the world to share in reading this work, it is our hope to honour Diane Di Prima and, through reading, activate and absorb the important instructions and revelations she left us in these letters.

?????????????
This event will be live captioned using Google Meet hardware. A PDF copy of the poems will be emailed to all registered attendees prior to the event, and a link to a PDF will be provided in the chat at the beginning of the reading. We will read 63 Revolutionary Letters together in varying length, which we project will take upwards of two hours to complete. We welcome you to email us at info@metatron-press.com if you have any further requests!

?????????
Adèle Barclay
Alasdair Rees
Alex Manley
Ali Pinkney

Content.contents:
Details
Event by Coach House Books
Online: eventbrite.ca
Price: Free
Public  · Anyone on or off Facebook
Join us for the launch of an important new anthology, Indigenous Toronto: Stories that Carry This Place.

Editors Denise Bolduc, Mnawaate Gordon-Corbiere, Rebeka Tabobondung, and Brian Wright-McLeod will be in discussion and will take audience questions.
Beneath many major North American cities rests a deep foundation of Indigenous history that has been colonized, paved over, and, too often, silenced. Few of its current inhabitants know that Toronto has seen twelve thousand years of uninterrupted Indigenous presence and nationhood in this region, along with a vibrant culture and history that thrives to this day.
With contributions by Indigenous Elders, scholars, journalists, artists, and historians, this unique anthology explores the poles of cultural continuity and settler colonialism that have come to define Toronto as a significant cultural hub and intersection that was also known as a Meeting Place long before European settlers arrived.
Contributors include political scientist Hayden King, artist and curator Wanda Nanibush, chef Johl Whiteduck Ringuette, poet and broadcaster Duke Redbird, playwright Drew Hayden Taylor, educator Kerry Potts, writer/journalist Miles Morrisseau, dancer and scholar Karen Pheasant-Neganigwane, and photographer Nadya Kwandibens.
Pre-order Indigenous Toronto here!
This event will be hosted in Zoom Webinars. The event link will be sent over email one hour before the start of the event.

Creators.notes: Editor of anthology

Creators.notes: Editor of anthology

Creators.notes: Editor of anthology

Related_Works.citation: Bolduc, Denise; Gordon-Corbiere, Mnawaate; Tabobondung, Rebeka; Wright-McLeod, Brian. Indigenous Toronto: Stories that Carry This Place. Toronto, Coach House, 2021.

collection.source_collection_description:
"Description": "Argo Bookshop is the oldest English-language independent bookstore in Montreal, located in the Shaughnessy Village since 1966. We're proud to offer a well-curated selection of fiction and non-fiction, including literature, poetry, science fiction and fantasy, science, philosophy, history, and biography. We also have sizable sections of young adult fiction and kids' books. We specialize in books on linguistics and Japan, as well as books on marginalized groups and by marginalized authors, including books on race, gender, and queer issues.",
"Wikidata": "https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q99472627",
"Contact Email": "info@argobookshop.ca",
"Twitter": "@ArgoBookshop",
"Facebook": "https://www.facebook.com/argobookshop",
"Organization Website": https://www.argobookshop.ca/

Content.contents:
Details
2 hr
Event by Ilona Martonfi
Online Event
Price: Free
Public  · Anyone on or off Facebook
Argo Zoom Reading Series: Verse, Prose & Song Thursday April 8, 2021 7 PM to 9 PM Free
Argo Bookshop 1915 Ste. Catherine St. West
https://www.argobookshop.ca/
Hosted by Adele-Elise Prevost & Moti Lieberman 514.931.3442
Curator Ilona Martonfi ilona.martonfi@sympatico.ca
Please email events@argobookshop.ca for the Zoom link
Devon Gallant is the author of four poetry collections including S(tars) & M(agnets) which bill bissett called ‘a mirakul uv a book.’
Susan Elmslie’s prize-winning poetry includes Museum of Kindness (Brick 2017) and I, Nadja, and Other Poems (Brick 2006). www.susan.elmslie.org
Ilona Martonfi is an editor, poet, curator & activist, her most recent poetry book is Salt Bride (Inanna, 2019). Forthcoming, The Tempest (Inanna, 2022).
Zsolt Alapi is an editor and publisher whose latest publication is his novel from DC Books, Landscape with the Fall of Icarus.
Michael Reinhart is a visual artist & musician, with 5 albums, numerous dance, theatre & film scores to his credit since the early ‘80s.
Lady Rojas Benavente, the author of Water Star (2017), is the president of the Canadian literary criticism of Hispanic American women writers.
Willow Loveday Little is a writer and editor whose work appears in places like The Dalhousie Review, On Spec, and yolk.
Matthew Rettino's poetry has recently appeared in Lantern Magazine's Dream issue this past January.
Tommy Schnurmacher is a broadcaster, author, humorist, and raconteur. Main regret? Not having worked as performance artist.

Creators.name: Martonfi, Ilona
Creators.notes:
Ilona refers to herself as the "Curator" of this series on the Facebook post, but she is effectively the series organizer.

Ilona Martonfi is an editor, poet, curator & activist, her most recent poetry book is Salt Bride (Inanna, 2019). Forthcoming, The Tempest (Inanna, 2022).

Content.contents:
Details
Event by Drawn and Quarterly
Duration: 1 hr
Public  · Anyone on or off Facebook
Adrian Tomine launches his highly anticipated graphic memoir The Loneliness of the Long-Distance Cartoonist with a series of virtual events in partnership with independent bookstores from around the United States.
Register now to hear Adrian interviewed by Wyatt Cenac, Malaka Gharib, Randall Park, Seth, Leanne Shapton, and Jason Zinoman!
Stay home, stay safe, stay connected.
Order your copy of The Loneliness of the Long-Distance Cartoonist directly from these bookstores to receive a special signed bookplate edition!

Content.contents:
Details
Event by Metonymy Press, Librairie Racines and 2 others
Online Event
Public  · Anyone on or off Facebook
In honour of the newly released picture book DEAR BLACK GIRLS, join Montreal artists and community members Shanice Nicole, Kezna Dalz, Maguy Métellus, and Nantali Indongo for a celebratory intergenerational discussion.
This is a free online event in collaboration with Librairie Racines.
Please register in advance:
https://us02web.zoom.us/.../reg.../WN_Kml_iKWyQA-CbyjF8e64mg
The even will also be on FB Live and Closed-captioning will be provided.
Order your copy of the book from Racines here: https://tinyurl.com/y4dte2v4
///////////////////////////////////////
DEAR BLACK GIRLS is a letter to all Black girls. Every single day poet and educator Shanice Nicole is reminded of how special Black girls are and of how lucky she is to be one. Illustrations by Kezna Dalz support the book’s message that no two Black girls are the same but they are all special—that to be a Black girl is a true gift. In this celebratory poem, Kezna and Shanice remind young readers that despite differences, they all deserve to be loved just the way they are.
///////////////////////////////////////
SHANICE NICOLE is a Black feminist educator, facilitator, writer, and (out)spoken word artist. She believes that everyone has the power to make change and dreams of a freer world for us all. Learn more about her work at shanicenicole.com.
KEZNA DALZ is a multidisciplinary Black artist from Montreal. She cares about representation, and portrays the beauty of womanhood, teenadult angst, and the worst of pop culture using vibrant colours. You can find more of her work at teenadultt.com.
MAGUY MÉTELLUS is a Haitiano-Quebecoise mother, grandmother, militante afroféministe, human rights advocate, diseuse and animatrice. In May 2016 she co-founded the Lectures Logos Readings with H. Nigel Thomas and the late Horace I. Goddard. Over the past twenty years she has become a staple in the community. She now revels in her new status as a beloved elder.
Daughter of parents from small Caribbean islands who, in Canada, became activists by circumstance, NANTALI INDONGO follows those natural instincts; carrying the torch into classrooms and communities, into studios and onto stages, with master's tools and microphones; exposing to educate, rhyming to rouse. All of that, so that the top tips over and humbles itself; the bottom sees the booby traps and makes an educated move.
As an artist, for the last 16 years, Nantali found her voice as Tali Taliwah, one of the emcees - vocalists in Montreal hip hop band Nomadic Massive. Touring Canada and the world, Tali loves to celebrate not only hip hop culture, but especially Caribbean musical cultures through some of her rhymes and vocal styles.
The life of the artist on stage was coupled with life as an artivist, for 10 years, sharing an educational and interactive workshop series that looks at the non-violent origins of Hip Hop culture. “Hip Hop No Pop” series that she co-created with founder and filmmaker, Maryse Legagneur, brought Nantali into communities and schools, specifically across Canada, to the US, to Haiti, Democratic Republic of Congo and Australia.
As an informal educator, broadcaster or performer, Nantali is a storyteller. Her sense of purpose: to push conversations forward to a place where positive inspiration becomes positive action.
Her 7 year old son is her spiritual healer.

Creators.name: Nicole, Shanice
Creators.notes: SHANICE NICOLE is a Black feminist educator, facilitator, writer, and (out)spoken word artist. She believes that everyone has the power to make change and dreams of a freer world for us all. Learn more about her work at shanicenicole.com.

Creators.name: Dalz, Kezna
Creators.notes: KEZNA DALZ is a multidisciplinary Black artist from Montreal. She cares about representation, and portrays the beauty of womanhood, teenadult angst, and the worst of pop culture using vibrant colours. You can find more of her work at teenadultt.com.

Creators.name: Métellus, Maguy
Creators.notes: MAGUY MÉTELLUS is a Haitiano-Quebecoise mother, grandmother, militante afroféministe, human rights advocate, diseuse and animatrice. In May 2016 she co-founded the Lectures Logos Readings with H. Nigel Thomas and the late Horace I. Goddard. Over the past twenty years she has become a staple in the community. She now revels in her new status as a beloved elder.

Creators.name: Nantali
Creators.notes: As an informal educator, broadcaster or performer, Nantali is a storyteller. Her sense of purpose: to push conversations forward to a place where positive inspiration becomes positive action.

Item_Description.title: DEAR BLACK GIRLS: Shanice Nicole, Kezna Dalz, Maguy Métellus & Nantali Indongo in conversation

Content.contents:
Details
Event by Accent Open Mic
Online: us02web.zoom.us
Public  · Anyone on or off Facebook
The Accent Reading Series and Cactus Press is pleased to announce the launch event for Ilona Martonfi's new poetry chapbook "Black Rain". A collection of poems ranging in free verse, ekphrastic poetry, prose poems, haiku, tanka, and haibun. This event will be followed with an open mic. Come one, come all.

Creators.name: Chiasson, Luc-Antoine
Creators.notes: Bio from Organization Website: Né à Shippagan, NB en 1989, vit à Montréal depuis 2009. Il partage son temps entre l’écriture et les arts visuels.

Creators.name: Gallant, Devon
Creators.notes: Bio from Organization Website: Devon Gallant is the author of four collections of poetry The Day After, the flower dress and other lines, His Inner Season, and S(tars) & M(agnets). His work has been previously published in Vallum, Carousel, Misunderstandings Magazine, Bitterzoet Magazine and elsewhere. He is the founder and publisher of Cactus Press. [devongallant.wordpress.com][cactuspresspoetry.wordpress.com]

Location.address: 5043 Saint Denis St, Montreal, Quebec, H2J 2L8

Related_Works.citation: Martonfi, Ilona. Black Rain, Cactus Press, 2021.

Item_Description.title: "Black Rain" by Ilona Martonfi - Cactus Press Chapbook Launch (+ Open Mic)
